channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukrainians Fear Russian Reprisals for Crimea Bridge Attack
item.description: Bitter over a strike against a vital bridge, Moscow hit civilian areas of Ukraine with a barrage of rockets, and some Ukrainians feared worse to come.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Michael Schwirtz and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in trenches taken from Russian forces in the Kherson region on Saturday.

item.title: 4 Weeks Out, Senate Control Hangs in the Balance in Tumultuous Midterms
item.description: The G.O.P. claimed the momentum in the spring. Then the overturning of Roe v. Wade galvanized Democrats. As the momentum shifts again, the final stretch of the 2022 midterms defies predictability.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Reid J. Epstein and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republicans are bullish on taking the House in November, but the Senate is up for grabs.

item.title: Arizona Governor Candidates Speak, and More Campaign News From the Sunday Shows
item.description: Katie Hobbs and Kari Lake were interviewed back-to-back on CBS, Stacey Abrams spoke on Fox News and Republicans stuck with Herschel Walker despite reports that he had paid for an abortion.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Hobbs, the Democratic nominee for governor in Arizona, at a voter registration event last month in Tempe.

item.title: 24 Hours in the Metaverse Version of Facebook Was Surprisingly Fun
item.description: Every hour of the day and night with the gamers, parents, insomniacs, preteens and aspiring comedians who are the earliest adopters of the immersive, three-dimensional internet that Mark Zuckerberg has bet the future of his company on.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: Brian Finke for The New York Times

item.title: How Colleen Hoover Rose to Rule the Best-Seller List
item.description: With legions of devoted fans and a knack for high-voltage emotional drama, Hoover has sold more than 20 million books. And she’s done it her way.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Jake Dockins for The New York Times
item.media:description: Colleen Hoover at home in Texas this month. “She’s defying the laws of how the market works,” said an industry analyst.

item.title: How California’s Bullet Train Went Off the Rails
item.description: America’s first experiment with high-speed rail has become a multi-billion-dollar nightmare. Political compromises created a project so expensive that almost no one knows how it can be built as originally envisioned.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction of the California high-speed rail system is costing about $1.8 million a day, according to projections widely used by engineers and project managers.

item.title: ‘Eye of Sauron’: The Dazzling Solar Tower in the Israeli Desert
item.description: Looming over a remote village in the Negev, the Ashalim solar plant is, for some, a marvel of green technology. For others, it’s a boondoggle and an eyesore.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Amit Elkayam
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shepherds near the Ashalim solar station. Completed in 2019, the tower generates enough electricity to power tens of thousands of homes.

item.title: After Racist Comments, Los Angeles City Council President Faces Calls to Resign
item.description: In a leaked recording of a meeting last year, she mocked Indigenous immigrants and the Black child of a fellow council member.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Al Seib/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Nury Martinez, president of the Los Angeles City Council.

item.title: An Empress Ahead of Her Time Is Having a Pop Culture Moment
item.description: A Netflix series and a new movie explore the life of Elisabeth, the 19th-century Empress of Austria who had a tattoo, worked out daily and wanted more from life than just producing heirs.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: The Exploitative Anti-Blackness of Kanye West
item.description: By wearing a “White Lives Matter” shirt, Kanye West gave white supremacists a boost.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: Joe Biden Knows How to Use Donald Trump
item.description: A lot of politicians would have vied with Trump to make the election about them.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein

item.title: What if Burnout Is Less About Work and More About Isolation?
item.description: Feeling burned out? Call your friends. Our real problem may be isolation.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren

item.title: Mismanagement and ‘Monster Trains’ Have Wrecked American Rail
item.description: Decades of cost-cutting takes a toll.
item.dc:creator: Justin Roczniak
item.media:credit: Universal Images Group via Getty Images

item.title: Chelsea Manning: ‘I’m Still Bound to Secrecy’
item.description: Five years after her release from prison, Chelsea Manning is still fighting to tell her story.
item.dc:creator: Chelsea Manning
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Lost Friend on My Mind
item.description: Paul disappeared years ago. Yet I see him everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Ellingson

item.title: Donald Trump and Herschel Walker: The Unholy Alliance
item.description: Republicans sink to a new low in defending Walker.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

item.title: The Brave Women Protesters in Iran Deserve More U.S. Support
item.description: Diplomatic efforts toward a nuclear deal must go hand in hand with American support for Iran’s protest movement.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Search for Intelligent Life Is About to Get a Lot More Interesting’
item.description: There are an estimated 100 billion galaxies in the universe, home to an unimaginable abundance of planets. And now there are new ways to spot signs of life on them.
item.dc:creator: Jon Gertner, Tally Abecassis, Marion Lozano, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Sharon Kearney

item.title: Talk of ‘Civil War’ Flares Online and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Revisiting Baldwin vs. Buckley
item.description: Nicholas Buccola talks about “The Fire Is Upon Us,” and Lydia Millet discusses “The Children’s Bible.”
item.media:credit: From left: Dave Pickoff/Associated Press; Associated Press
item.media:description: The 1965 debate between James Baldwin and William F. Buckley Jr. at the Cambridge Union was a crucial battle in the fight over civil rights.

item.title: Tell Us: What Questions About Climate Change Can We Answer?
item.description: There is no question too basic, or too big. Your suggestions will be used to help guide the Times’s climate coverage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Landslides in Venezuela Leave at Least 22 Dead and Dozens Missing
item.description: The Venezuelan armed forces planned to deploy canines and drones to find missing residents and to deliver food and medicine.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Tibisay Romero
item.media:description: Mud coursed through the streets of Las Tejerías, Venezuela, over the weekend.

item.title: Kanye West’s Antisemitic Posts Land Him in Trouble on Instagram and Twitter
item.description: The rapper, who now goes by Ye, made antisemitic remarks on Instagram and Twitter that were widely criticized. They came after he wore a “White Lives Matter” shirt at Paris Fashion Week.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ye, the rapper formerly known as Kanye West, at a Paris fashion show last week.

item.title: Mets Season Ends With Wild-Card Loss to Padres
item.description: Stuck in the wild-card round despite 101 wins, the Mets had no answers for San Diego, which took two of three games to advance to a division series.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Michelle Farsi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked to keep the Mets’ season alive, Chris Bassitt lasted only four innings on Sunday. He allowed three earned runs and took the loss.

item.title: A Minecraft Player Set Out to Build the Known Universe, Block by Block
item.description: Christopher Slayton, 18, spent two months intricately designing the planets. He even went skydiving to get a better appreciation for Earth.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:description: Christopher Slayton created his version of the universe in Minecraft, a video game where users can fashion a world out of virtual blocks.

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal

item.title: Gut Healing Is TikTok’s Latest Trend. Does It Work?
item.description: Despite what social media might have you believe, there is no overnight shortcut to better digestive health.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Sophie Park
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: “Savor,” by Fatima Ali
item.description: In “Savor,” readers get to know Fatima Ali, the brave woman who was beloved by Food Network audiences and her family.
item.dc:creator: Mary Pols

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
